I was helping to build my resume and wanted to use job descriptions from various similar job titles. I input a bunch of those job descriptions into ChatGPT and created a keyword hotspot to see which ones were the most common, which I could then use.

One of the main daily uses of AI that I hope will occur sooner rather than later is a more nuanced task listing tool.

I would like to see a way to view my to-do list and track my grocery shopping history. It would be great if there were suggestions, like, "Hey, it's approaching Christmas. Have you considered getting X, Y, Z?" or "It's October; maybe consider more pumpkin-style dishes."
having AI handle accounting tasks would be incredibly helpful.
Right now, the notes app on Apple is okay for list building and to-do lists, but it could be radically improved.

I'd like suggestions specifically for the grocery store list. It's like, "Hey, here are the most common items that you have." If you consider this, here are items that other people also bought. Here are some dish suggestions.
At the moment, it's just very clunky and manual.
imagine being able to ask an AI assistant to send email invites to events or maybe for family gatherings.

I would say that this felt like a very light, weak version. It just felt like there's a little bit of AI in the background, but it wasn't actually like being interviewed by an AI in the sense that we typically think of it, maybe like in a sci-fi movie.
I think AI would just have to advance so much that the gap between humans and the ability to mimic humans becomes so close that it's indistinguishable.
It's also interesting how AI often looks too clean, crisp, and fake. There's something called the uncanny valley.
It's either make it look like a cartoon and not try to approximate a human, or make it look exactly like a human.
You have to intentionally code scenarios that create all these imperfections that are inherently human, which is what leads to authenticity.
